questions.text: Which of the following is not a vital statistic?
questions.solution:
Sex ratio is not a vital statistic, it is a population statistic.

Demographic indicators have been divided into 2 parts:

  • Population statistics include -
    • Population size
    • Sex ratio
    • Density
    • Dependency ratio
  • Vital statistics include -
    • Birth rate
    • Death rate
    • Natural growth rate
    • Life expectancy at birth
    • Mortality rate
    • Fertility rate

questions.text: While conducting a demographic study, you need to calculate the total dependency ratio of the study population. Which of the following will you include in the numerator while calculating this?

choices.text: Population under 10 years and above 60 years
Population under 15 years and above 60 years
Population under 10 years and above 65 years
Population under 15 years and above 65 years

questions.solution:
Population under 15 years and above 65 years are part of the numerator used to calculate the total dependency ratio. This is because this population is considered the dependant population.

The dependant population includes children below 15 years of age and adults above 65 years of age. The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15 - 65 years. It is also called the societal dependency ratio. It can also be divided into the young-age and old-age dependency ratios.

Note: As of mid-year 2020, the dependency ratio of India is 48.7%.

questions.text: While studying a community, the researcher found 30% of the population to be below 15 years of age, and 10% was over 65 years of age. What is the total dependency ratio of this population?
questions.solution:
The total dependency ratio in this population is 66.6%. 

This can be calculated as follows.

Here, the total population below 15 years of age is = 30%

Total population above 65 years of age = 10%

So, total population between 15-65 years of age = 100 - (30 + 10) = 60%

Hence, dependency ratio in this population = 100* (30% + 10%)/60% = 66.6%

questions.text: What is potential support ratio?

choices.text: Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per child below 15 years or less
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per older person aged 65 or more
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per each older person aged >65 and younger person aged < 15
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per each older person aged > 60 and younger person aged <15

questions.solution: The potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more. It is the inverse of the old-age dependency ratio.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major contributor to demographic burden?
questions.solution:
Demographic burden refers to an increase in the total dependency ratio. It is mostly caused by an increased old-age dependency ratio.

The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility. A decline in dependency ratio especially the young-age dependency ratio has been identified to be a key factor in the underlying rapid economic development.

The potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more. This is the inverse of the old-age dependency ratio.

questions.text: Which of the following determines the carrying capacity of a population?
questions.solution: The carrying capacity is the number of individuals of a population that can be supported for a period of time given the resources of that area. Thus, the carrying capacity is determined by the limiting resources of an area.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about crude birth rate?
questions.solution:
The numerator of crude birth rate only includes live births and does not include stillbirths.

Crude birth rate = No. of live births during the year x 1000/ Estimated mid-year population

questions.text: As part of the national maternity benefit scheme, you have been tasked with conducting a study in a community of 5000 people.  What is the expected number of pregnant women in this community if the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people?
questions.solution:
The expected number of pregnant females in the given community would be 165.

Step 1: In the given question, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people i.e 30 children are born from pregnant mothers for every 1000 people. Therefore there are 30 pregnant females per 1000 population.

Step 2: Since the total population is 5000, the total no of pregnant females = 5000 x 30/1000 = 150 

Step 3: Since some pregnancies may not result in live births (abortions and stillbirths), a correction factor of 10% should be added to avoid the underestimation of the number of pregnancies. Pregnancy wastage (i.e 10% of total live births) =10 x 150/100=15.

Step 4: Total pregnant females = total live births + pregnancy wastage = 150+15=165.

questions.text: According to NFHS-5, what is the sex ratio in India?
questions.solution:
According to the NFHS-5 (2019-21), the sex ratio in India is 1020 females per 1000 males. It has increased from the 2011 Census which had found a sex ratio of 940 females per 1000 males.

The sex ratio at birth is 929 females per 1000 males.

The National Girl Child Day is celebrated in India every year on January 24. It was initiated by the Ministry of Women and Child Development. The day is celebrated with objectives of generating awareness on the declining child sex ratio and creating a positive environment around the girl child.

Related Pearl: Sex Ratio

  • It is the number of females per 1000 males.
  • According to NFHS-5 (2019-21), the sex ratio in India was 1020 females per 1000 males.
  • As per Census 2011, India had a sex ratio of 940 females per 1000 males. Hence, we can see the sex ratio has improved.
  • Kerala was the only state to hold a favourable sex ratio in the last census. It currently holds a sex ratio of 1121 females per 1000 males. (NFHS-5 data)
  • Puducherry was the only union territory that had a favourable sex ratio in the last census. It currently has a sex ratio of 1112 females per 1000 males. (NFHS-5 data)
  • The sex composition of the population is affected by the differentials in mortality conditions of males and females, sex-selective migration and the sex ratio at birth.
  • A very low sex ratio indicates male-child favoritism.

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, what does a sex ratio of more than 1000 mean?
questions.solution:
For a population of 10000, if the sex ratio is more than 1000, it means males are less than 5000 i.e., less than half the population.

The sex ratio refers to the number of females per 1000 males. An ideal sex ratio would be 1000, indicating the population comprises an equal number of males and females.

Sex ratio >1000 indicates that there are more females than males in a population. Sex ratio <1000 indicates that there are fewer females compared to males in the population.

questions.text: What is the definition of the net reproduction rate?

choices.text: No. of children that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of girls  that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of female children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate

questions.solution:
Net reproduction rate (NRR) is defined as the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate.

India is aiming for an NRR of 1 as it is equivalent to the two-child norm.

questions.text:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?

NRR: Net reproduction rate
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: What is the infant mortality rate in India as per the SRS Statistical Report (2020)?
questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate (IMR) in India as per the SRS statistical report (2020) is 28 per 1000 live births. 

IMR is defined as the number of infant deaths for every 1000 live births. As per the National Family Health Survey - 5 (2019-2021), the IMR is 35.2 per 1000 live births.

IMR is considered the best indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care.

questions.text: Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for a country is best given as __________
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: What is the maternal mortality ratio in India according to the Special Bulletin on Maternal Mortality (2018-2020) based on SRS data?
questions.solution:
The maternal mortality ratio (MMR) in India according to the Special Bulletin (2018-2020) based on SRS data is 97.

MMR is defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.

The most common causes of maternal mortality in India are postpartum hemorrhage and infections.

questions.text: While collecting data for the census, which of the following people would you consider to be literate?

choices.text: A person who is able to read, write and understand in any language
A person who is not able to read or write but can sign legal documents
A person who is able to speak fluently in his native language but is not able to read or write
A person who is able to read, but may not be able to write

questions.solution:
A person is considered literate if he or she can read, write and understand in any language.

questions.text: What is the denominator of the formula used to calculate effective literacy rate?

choices.text: Population less than 15 years of age

questions.solution:
The denominator used to calculate the effective literacy rate is the population aged 7 years or more. It is calculated as follows.

Effective literacy rate = Number of literate persons aged 7 and above x 100/ Population aged 7 and above in a given year.

This rate is generally used in Indian censuses including those in 1991, 2001, and 2011 for estimating literacy.

questions.text: You are studying the literacy rate of a community with a total population of 10000. Out of these, there are 2000 children from 0-6 years of age, and 4000 literate individuals above 7 years of age. What is the effective literacy rate of this population?
questions.solution:
The effective literacy rate of this population is 50%. 

It is calculated as follows,

Effective literacy rate = (Number of literate persons aged 7 and above x 100) / population aged 7 and above in a given year. 

In the given scenario, people aged 7 years and above = 10000 - 2000 = 8000. Out of these 8000 people, 4000 are literate.

Thus, effective literacy rate = 4000 x 100/8000 = 50%.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the criteria for an urban Indian city?

choices.text: Having a density of 390 persons per square km
At least half of the adult male population employed in occupations other than agriculture

questions.solution:
In an urban area, at least three-fourths of the adult male population are employed in occupations other than agriculture.

In the Indian context, the urban areas are places:

  • having 5,000 or more inhabitants
  • having a density of not less than 1,000 persons per square mile or 390 per square kilometer
  • having pronounced urban characteristics
  • having at least three-fourths of the adult male population employed in pursuits other than agriculture
